questions.definition: A group of planets, moons, and other celestial objects that orbit a central star.
A large, round celestial object that orbits a star and has cleared its orbit of debris.
A massive sphere of hot gases that emits light and energy due to nuclear fusion.
A vast collection of stars, gas, dust, and dark matter held together by gravity.
The curved path an object follows as it moves around another object in space due to gravity.
An object that orbits a planet or star, which can be natural or human-made.
A small rocky object that orbits the Sun, mostly found in a belt between Mars and Jupiter.
A celestial object made of ice and dust that develops a glowing tail when near the Sun.
A streak of light produced when a small space rock burns up in Earth's atmosphere.
A region in space with such strong gravity that not even light can escape.
A massive cloud of gas and dust in space where stars can form.
The distance light travels in one year, about 9.46 trillion kilometers.
The leading explanation for the origin of the universe, stating it began from a very hot, dense state.
A planet that orbits a star outside of our solar system.
The scientific study of celestial objects, space, and the universe as a whole.
A robotic spacecraft that gathers data from space and sends it back to Earth.
A natural force of attraction that pulls objects toward one another, giving them weight.
A reusable spacecraft used to transport astronauts and cargo to and from space.
A person trained to travel and work in space.
A vehicle designed to propel itself into space using powerful engines.
A large telescope in Earth's orbit that captures detailed images of space.
A late stage in a star's life when it expands and cools after running out of hydrogen fuel.
A massive explosion that occurs when a large star reaches the end of its life.
A rapidly rotating neutron star that emits beams of radiation.
A mysterious substance that does not emit light but exerts gravitational effects in the universe.
